Ok - this is quite interesting. But Destin - you are not really finished with this topic. Because at a certain point - at a certain distance from the bow, the arrow (should) stop deflecting - it should straighten up and fly straight. How soon it does that, depends on quite some factors: Type of bow (longbow, recurve with plunger, compound bow), how clean the release is (fingers / mechanical release) and most important maybe how well the arrow fits to the bow. I.e. if the static and dynamic spine matches the bow perfectly or not. This can be tested with for example paper tuning tests, closer or farther away from the bow. If I recall longbow and recurve archers don't use paper tuning, they use bareshaft tuning, while compound archers uses paper tuning. I actually don't know if it is because from longbow / recurve, the arrow will flex all the way to the target - or if it stop flexing at a long distance that you normally not do paper tuning tests. Maybe the paper tuning test to some extend could show that. But maybe slow motion filming is better, because at a random distance, you could be lucky that the arrow goes straight through the paper, because at that point it is in a straight point of the flex. So that could require quite a lot of tests. With compound bow / leverbow, the goal is to have the arrow stop flexing at the shortest distance from the bow as possible. For example because, in 3D archery, you might need to shoot at a target, that is very close to you (and it can actually be difficult to hit a very close target in a finger diameter spot, if your setup is not well tuned etc.).
This is one of the coolest topics I have ever seen tackled on this channel.
The mass of the arrow head also has a big influence. More mass up front results in higher inertia and more flex under dynamic loading. :)

When you are an archer, there are three things that you need to know. Your personal arrow length, the strength of your bow and your spine. The spine is not determined by your opinion, it is calculated from your arrow length and bow strength. If your spine is too flexible, it'll fly of to the right and if it's too hard, it'll fly of to the left. An arrow is only flying 'straight' when you have the correct spine suited for you. The rest is skill.

By skill is meant that there are many more factors than your spine that determine your accuracy, at least for recurve and longbows. The placement of your arrow on the bowstring, how you pull the arrow, how you grip the bow, how you release the arrow and even how you breathe while doing all of this.

well yes and no, the bow, arrow, and string not lining up does do this, but even if the string and bow were perfectly lined up the arrow will still bend due to the fact that the object does not want to accelerate. you applied a force directly to the back of the arrow and it accelerates, but the rest of the arrow does not want to, this creates a scenario where it is just as if the bow and string are not lined up, it will have a lesser degree of effect but it will still happen, that is why you still see it happen on the compound bow.

Another trick he uses is that his longbow has a shooting notch in it, I noticed. There will still be significantly more wobble in the arrow than a modern compound bow, but the notch helps compared to a traditional English warbow, which had no notch and therefore would push the arrow to the side more. The wobble of his arrow is present, but not much more than one arrow width. Also, I assume, perhaps incorrectly, that he shoots from a known distance so that he can always hit at the nodal point, similar to knife throwing. All that said, even if the wobble didn't matter in his shots whatsoever (but it does to some degree), his accuracy, precision, and timing are unreal. I.e. on the first two, his accuracy is how close to center he consistently hits and his precision is how small a group he can consistently hit. Most modern pistol, or even rifle, shooters cannot hit a moving target the size of an aspirin at any distance, and plinksters usually spend much more time aiming their shot that he does.

I was wondering if you could possibly do some videos on how a fly drifts in relation to the fishing line or what fly fisherman call tippit. The goal is to not have a fly be pulled by the tippit. I enjoy a  style of fly fishing where you use flies with a tungsten bead to sink. And very thin tippit to cut through the water. ‘Eastern’ style archery eliminates pretty much all of what you’re talking about hear... the ‘western’ style views it more as a science or from a rifle shooting point of view rather than a natural occurrence. Which is interesting... look at the way an ‘Eastern’ archer shoots sometime: loads the arrow on the opposite side of the rest, releases with the thumb via a thumb ring, and drops the bow away to the opposite side the arrow is resting... these are skills that many modern compound bow shooters utilize through mechanical manipulation... when the Asian and Arabic archers of the past already had a simple ‘recurve’ figured out through technique alone. Food for thought! Not knocking old man’s skills as he is extremely good for western style! I’ve shot a lot of western myself but am now just finding the simplicity and accuracy that was attained through the Asian styles. Maybe a comparison video should be in the works for you in the future. Regardless, archery should be a journey of self enlightenment! God bless and thanks for the video!

This video has some great science, but there is also the human factor.  Your brain will learn after multiple attempts what to do and where to aim even if you don't fully understand what is happening to the arrow.  Sort of like axe throwing or shooting hoops.  Axe throwers know that the distance to target is the most important thing and they have to throw at a distance that will have the blade around at target.  Basketball players spend most of their time practicing the 3 point line and free throws.  But do you actually have to understand the physics?  I don't know.  I think your brain programs itself through repetition.  Making sure the arrow you are shooting has the same characteristics as the arrows you trained with probably improves accuracy because it removes a variable.  But the brain having fired a thousand shots and having evaluated the results is probably more important.  I've shot some arrows before, and never really thought about the physics of the particular arrow, but you never hit the bullseye by aiming straight at it.  Wind, distance, if you naturally shoot high or left, it all factors in.  Same even with guns over a long distance.  If your windage and elevation is set well for target shooting at 50 feet, it probably won't get that deer at 1000 feet.  So you can set it all up for 1000 feet, but you still have to correct for windage.

The arrow bends because the force of the string puts the arrow into elastic buckling.  If the arrow was PULLED rather than PUSHED, then the arrow would not bend.  In order to PULL the arrow,  the archer would need a bow with the string in front, rather than the back.  Also, there would have to be a hook of some sort in front in order to effectively "notch" the arrow to the string.  I created a little bow design that does incorporate these features.

Poundage of the bow must be approximately 1/10th of the dynamic spine for the arrow to fly straight.

I ain't no big city engineer but, all that wiggling takes energy to make happen, right? That energy would be part of the energy released from the bow, transmitted to the arrow via the bowstring.
Point being, if the bow were constructed to not block the line of thrust, and the arrow were constructed as rigid as possible, more energy would be applied to accelerate the arrow.
Therefore, more applied energy equals greater range, and/or kinetic energy for the target to absorb.
Just a theory...

Loved the video, but this is a rare case where I didn't feel like it was fully explained. Destin said at 6:14 "at a certain distance from his bow he still has to know which side of the arrow that wobble's going to be on, and then he has to line that up." That implies the archer would have to aim slightly left or right of the target based on the distance and where the wobble would be at that moment. But I've read that the wobble frequency is somewhere in the realm of 90 Hz. At an arrow speed of 180fps that would be an oscillation every two feet. To be certain of hitting a tiny target you would have to judge the distance within perhaps 3-4 inches and then apply some difficult math to know how far left or right to adjust. It only seems possible to pull off a trick shot like that if you've pre-determined the exact distance to ensure the tip would be centered on contact so you can aim directly at the target. Even with all that it's a remarkable feat of skill, but it seems a bit far-fetched to suggest that the archer would ever actually make a manual adjustment for arrow wobble based on distance.

So - to sum it up: what seems like a drawback on the arrow support in the compound bow (it does not fold back fast enough, so it is going to be hit by the arrow) actually is an advantage, because you add the vibration/wobble to the arrow with it? Which would render e.g. a spring loaded mechanism to allow for faster contraction time of the support structure pretty useless? Right?

Which makes me think a bit more "out loud" about it: there are some techniques to stabilize fast travelling object's flight, such as a spin (think of a rifle; they have grooves or a comparable structure which adds a spin to the bullet and stabilizes it by doing so). I guess the vibration of the arrow also adds some stabilization, but if one could design a compound bow which adds a rotation instead of a "wobble" vibration to the arrow...

One aspect of the archer's paradox that I don't ever see really discussed in media like this is that you're not aiming through the bow, you're aiming around it. you're using the tangent that the arrow will take to guide your shot. which is why, if you'll notice he has his bow tilted slightly, you draw the string back and slightly up, to increase the stress on the arrow when loosed, and then you drop the bow  EVER so slightly on the start of the follow-through in order to minimize the obstructions to the arrow on it's path.

The fletching of the arrow is a pure physics. When we release the string, the potential energy on the limbs are transferred to the string, and then to the knocking point (back) of the arrow, converting the energy into kinetic as it pushing the back of the arrow forward.

The problem is, the arrow tip (front) doesn't have that energy yet. Because the energy transfer between each tip takes time.. Now imagine... You have a stick. And give one of the tip a huge kinetic energy that propels it toward the other tip. The tip you gave energy, will move forward. But the other tip, although it will also move forward, it moves slower than the tip which receive the energy. If the front tip is moving slower and the back tip is moving faster, what happen to the stick? Yep... It fletched. This is why, although compound bows (and modern recurve bows) which set the arrow straight (hence, no archer's paradox), the arrow will fletched all the time.

The arrow is vibrating at a very high frequency, switching sides probably hundreds of times per second. Meaning his distance judging would have to be accurate to the centimetre. Even when asked about it, he doesn't answer because he himself doesn't know. And knowing the stiffness of the arrow tells you nothing about which side it will be swivelling at a certain distance. He hit the aspirin either out of luck, or at a distance where the swivelling died down enough to be negligible.

I thought this was going to be about Zeno’s dichotomy paradox which I have seen represented by an arrow in flight. The arrow on its way to the target must get to a halfway point, and then the halfway point of the remaining distance, and then the halfway point of THAT remaining distance and so on. Since the arrow is always moving to a halfway point of smaller and smaller distances, it will always be approaching the target but never hit it.

I am 25% Kazak. Something like Imperial Russia cowboys, but with bows, sabres and guns. And my granddad, who is 100% Kazak, taught me how to use a bow and how to shoot. The thing is, mounted archery and archery in the fields are all about morale damage, about how often death is coming from the sky, and how to shoot while you don't have time for aim.

You take a bow in left hand, arrow in right, place arrow on the right side of a bow. You won't have aim at all, but you don't need it! You won't have time for it either way. But you are not doing that awkward arrow-over-bow-and-back movement and can shoot at maximum speed.

So, your arrow on the side with a hand that's holding it. How you shoot? First, your bow must be a little rotated counterclockwise. So your thumb and bow would make v-shape. It is not nesessary, but you need to get used to it. You aim with your hand... body... instincts! Before drawing. Then you shoot. In one movement you draw and release it. Every micro-second after full draw would be a tension that would affect your accuracy. Yeah, maybe you won't have 100% on the first shot, but while others would make 1 you will finish with 3-5 of them. And total damage would be enourmous. (Even with 33% accuracy, one would hit the mark.)

Kazaks were all about fast ambushes with seconds of fighting and immideate retreat. Something that later would be called "partizan's tactic. In seconds mounted warriors would do several kills and slashing would with their curvee blades (Shashka) and make dozen of shots into the unknowing formation. They'd be gone before you'll form any type of formation. Before 1st World War this was unchallangable strategy in the swamps and forests of Mother Russia and Ukraine.

This sort of idea of a "wobbling" projectile well not really wobbling for most ship cannons where the cannon balls rotate or spin during flight, this is great for sharp angles for the projectile to fly across the opposing ship's haul which would in turn weaken the haul with the right angle, of course it doesnt mean a straight strike against the haul is a good idea if you are getting hit as your ship will still take a lot of damage if your haul takes an entire broadside headon, a similar rule for tanks when it comes to angles, infact speaking of angles, you may think a shield that is able to deflect arrows is a good idea, well if you move closer to a defense position, the arrow retains more power and you are most likely moving in formation

This is made to seem more complex than it is. The tip and back of the arrow never move. You don't need to predict anything about that wobble to hit a target with the tip of the arrow. It oscillates on the middle part of the arrow, creating a U shape. There would be more of a W shape if the tip wasn't always flying in a straight line. Still an incredible shot, but the number of variables if the tip were moving away from that center point would be pretty well similar to predicting the placement of an electron in its orbit; aka it's impossible.

To be absolutely correct, the Archer's paradox doesn't point just to the fact that the arrow points sideways because the bow is in the way, it's the fact that the arrow will point further and further sideways as you reduce the length of draw. The paradox basically refers to the difference of angle your arrow experiences from full draw to total release from the bow.

Great explanation, however I feel one crucial bit was left out: the reason that you can't just center-cut a bow that's designed for finger release.

The reason for this is the fact that when fingers release a string, the string (and nocked arrow) will always jump to one side, no matter how clean your release may be. That's why you start off with the arrow at an offset. It's also why a compound bow (which uses a release aid) doesn't have archer's paradox.

Other than that, great slo-mo!

It is also worth noting how this phenomenon also shaped the design of medieval era castles. The arrow loop is a very narrow "window" for archers in the castle to shoot out of while being almost 100.00% safe from return fire. The architecture that went into constructing them ensured that the archer would fire at a precise distance so that the wobble of the arrow would still fit through the arrow loop without the arrow hitting the sides of the wall as it exited. This extra distance also ensured that even if an arrow got through the arrow loop from the outside, it would be much more likely to miss the archer inside than hit them.

While they didn't allow for a great line of sight for attacking intruders from many angles, arrow loops would be built around much of the castle and occupied by two or three archers each. This allowed for arrow after arrow to be shot at intruders very quickly in places where intruders had to cross to enter the castle, such as the portcullis (castle gate). The tops of the walls and towers would be lined with crenulations for the archers on top to take cover while firing. While they didn't have as much cover, they could shoot at targets in zones where the archers occupying the arrow loops could not reach, or supplement their fire.

These walls also protruded out slightly at the top, and had holes in the bottom at the edges of the floor called machicolations that allowed defending archers to shoot straight down as well as outward. This meant that if an intruder "hugged the wall", they could still be shot by defenders.

Totally being disregarded is the weight of the broadhead/tip at the front of the arrow.  That's the heaviest part of the arrow. For just a few milliseconds it remains stationary - because it takes more ENERGY  to get it moving - while the lighter portion of the arrow begin moving forward! This makes the arrow shaft bend - the nock end of the arrow is moving forward while the tip is still stationary. Since the bow is in the way of the arrow flexing THAT direction, it must flex outward. The shelf/arrow cutout on many long bows and recurves puts the arrow in line with the string travel, so that point is not valid.

A rifle barrel does something similar, it actually flexes as the bullet is launched towards and out the muzzle. To be accurate, a rifle needs to behave consistently, one shot to the next. The fine tuning involves mounting the barrelled action solidly and altering the ammo components and powder charge to find a combination that works best.

*When shooting at, or around mirrors with a bow, be cautious of the 'reflection paradox'*
It states, that, if the mirror is set at a specific angle, so that the visual reflection angle is at the point of "ideal reflectal azimuth", the odds are 100.00% that the "visual arrow reflection" will become the literal arrow, and your arrow will hit you at exactly the spot you aimed at in the mirror.

This is awesome, but at 7:08 you can see that the tip of the arrow doesn't wobble very much (only a maybe 1 cm) so it seems to be at (or near) a node, making the aspirin shot a bit easier. It seems like the main antinode is near the center of the shaft with one node near the tip and the other one near the fletching. I have never seen any archer calculate the movement of the arrow when shooting. Anyone pretending to do so would be a liar. The best traditional bow shooters shoot many arrows (i mean A LOT here) and end up knowing instinctively how to get the arrow in the target. All the ones i know say they miss if they start thinking too much.

The stiffness of an arrow (shaft) as calculated in the video does not indicate how much it will bend or rotate. The weight of the arrow tip, nock and feather. the amount of pressure of the bow, the type of string used and the emplacement where the arrow is nocked also have a big influence in the arrow reaction and are used to fine tune the equipment. There are other factor in the archer technique as well (how he holds the bow, how fast he releases, the bow mouvement at release, etc). Those are not calculated by the machine he is using. The purpose of this machine is to make sure that all arrows have the same shaft stiffness. Thats all.

You're having a laugh, right? There is no paradox, at all, ever. If you use a rigid arrow, the arrow does not fly to the target. Two different things, behaving in two different ways are not paradoxical.

Maybe I learned this wrong, but I had throught the bend came purely from the massive force of the bow pushing against the mass of the arrow, which resists movement. Hence it will compress as the back accellerates faster than the front and then the average acceleration during the period up until it leaves the string determines the acceleration of the center of mass, which gives it the exit velocity. Without the deflection, the resistence would lead to heat and sound rather than be absorbed by the arrow so it can spring back and translate into forward momentum.

If you need an armguard, you're holding the bow wrong. Maybe for the expert there, it has something to do with how he holds it to do his trick shots? But for basic target shooting, the guard should only be necessary because mistakes are easy to make. When I was practicing every day, I rarely wore one and almost never hit my arm. The key is that if you hold it like a hammer, it will hit your arm. If you hold it along the line of your palm, it moves your arm out of the way of the string, and then when you release, it can't hit your arm.

EDIT: I watched in a couple of those shots. The way he's holding the bow is similar to how I learned. There's no way he's hitting that arm guard. My guess is he wears it to set a good example for less experienced archers.

Something to consider: The bow is not (necessarily) pointed at the target. The arrow is pointed at the target. Seems like a minor difference, but it's an important distinction. With proper spine and arrow tip (weight) selection - as Byron discusses - one can overcome the effects of arrow flex to achieve accuracy on target. On the other hand, if you don't point the arrow at the target, it's pretty much guaranteed that you won't hit it.
If the archer's paradox operates as you explained in the video, perhaps I can ask the obvious, illogical question: how wide can a bow's riser be before the arrow stops "flexing around" it? Put another way: per your depiction, the arrow will still make its way to the target no matter how wide the riser is.
The common misconception regarding the archer's paradox comes as a result of the inappropriate conflation of two unrelated concepts: arrow flex and archery aiming. Arrows do flex - some of this may be caused by interaction with the bow, but it is mainly due to the stresses imparted on the arrow system (nock, shaft, arrowhead) during the firing sequence. When aiming an archery shooting system (bow, string, arrow), one isn't actually aiming the bow toward the target, but rather is aiming the arrow toward the target.
Funny enough, you actually showed this via the use of the toy bow and crossbow at the beginning of the video. You aimed the suction cup dart directly at the camera and succeeded in hitting it. The bow just happened to be aimed directly at the target as well.
If you'd like to test this - and I'd love to see you do so - you will need center-shot bow. You might start with bow that has a modern olympic-style riser on which you can verify true center-shot. Tune the bow so that it achieves accuracy on target according to accepted standards of tuning and aiming. On a side note: If you use a peep sight, you'll immediately see that you're aiming to the target along the arrow, not the bow. When properly tuned, this setup will provide a bow-target line that is exactly parallel to the arrow-target line. Just like the toy bow you used earlier.
Next, build up the riser with ever-thicker shims between it and the arrow - this is to simulate the use of a non-center-shot bow (like a long bow). If you maintain the bow's position relative to the target you will find that - while the bow-target line remains the same - the arrow-target line has shifted. This will naturally result in a shift of the arrow's point of impact. You might use a couple laser aiming devices to illustrate this shift. Can you guess where the arrow will hit now?

Arrows still flex when fired from a center-shot bow, so it remains important to select shafts with the right spine for the draw weight of the bow (again, as per Byron). Among other things, a properly-tuned center-shot bow simply reduces any effects the bow may have on the arrow during the firing cycle.

FYI, there is a device called a "plunger" that sits just behind the arrow rest. The plunger is a spring loaded button. As the string is drawn it pushes against against the plunger button. When the arrow is released the tension on the button is loosened and it starts pushing against the arrow shaft causing it to fly strait. Most bow makers place a pre-drilled hole in the riser for the plunger. Note: almost all arrows in flight will "swim" to some degree.

Wow, the arrow doesn't do what you describe as is evident by the slow motion footage.

The string is in line with the bow and the arrow, engaged with the string in the center, is resting on a cutaway but puts the arrow left of center by ~15mm. The aim for the bow isn't to line up the string with the bow with the center target. The aim is to look down the arrow and have the arrow pointing at center target.

Your tree analogy is flawed because you overly exaggerate the deflection. The actual deflection? Very small and easily compensated for.

After all, if you look closely at the slow motion around 3:20, the arrow actually bends in the opposite direction than the described scenario regarding the tree and the arrow, despite the initial deflection, is pushed forward straight. The deflection barely even changes (a few mm) as the string pushes it forward.

As for the Aspirin? Part luck and part the fact that the tip of the arrow actually doesn't oscillate all that far from center. I have, unfortunately, broke plenty of notches off the back of my arrows by hitting them with another arrow. I once drove a second arrow into the back end of the previous causing it to split. But is energy wasted when the arrow wobbles in flight or does it actually help the arrow stay above ground for longer?

It would be nice to compare a bow and crossbow of exact draw length, draw weight and have them shoot the same arrow (or even make one arrow stiffer for the crossbow) and see which arrow has more energy.

Most crossbows back in day especially in the medieval times had high draw weights but short draw lengths, this meant a 350lb crossbow wasn't that powerful, this also resulted in shorter arrows which were called bolts or quarrels. Since they were shorter, they would probably have little to no wobbling in flight.

My hypothesis is that a bit of energy would be wasted for the arrow. Also, when an arrow impacts a target, it continues to wobble, where as a short crossbow bolt would not wobble. Kind of like throwing a knife at a target. Most knives that are designed for throwing are stiff and do not flex due to the making of them. However, knife throwers can throw tools/weapons that aren't designed for throwing. A kitchen knife can be thrown and stick in a wooden target, but most kitchen knives are flexible so when the knife sticks, the knife wobbles so some energy is lost.

I thought Archer's Paradox was because since arrows are long, they bend easy, so when the string is released, some of the energy is used to make the arrow wobble in flight. I didn't think the bow itself would cause that issue.

This is not a paradox.
A paradox is a situation or statement that contradicts itself, like....
simultaneously existing & not existing... or 1+1 = 2 & not 2.

If a situation or phenomenon can be logically explained through, observation, experimentation, or philosophical reasoning... it is not a paradox.

This is a classic case of people misusing a word out of context... calling it a paradox... because people where under the misconception that arrows fly straight.

Bullets & laser beams do not fly straight either.

nice vid but one little mistake. the bending of the arrow does not come only from the arrow flying around the bow. it comes from mass inertia. the moment you release an arrow the kinetic energy transforms into it and a part of this energy causes the arrow to compress. this compression then transforms into this "wabbling" movment of the arrow. at 2:50 you can see that the bow has a part cut off so the arrow lies in a straight line and does not have to bend around the arrow (at least not very much).

The more advanced your compound bow, the more rigid you can have your arrow = less kinetic energy lost to the flexing of the arrow = more joules of energy delivered for damaging your target.

This is what allows an advanced compound bow to take down a full grown buck, from a reasonable distance, when it is only set at 40lbs to 50lbs on the arms. Older bows needed to be set to 70lbs-80lbs with 70-90% let-off to achieve the same efficiency and it was much harder to draw the bow and hold it fully drawn much like a long bow that can be 40lbs to 70lbs with 0% let-off

1) the longbow is notched in the middle, rendering his "bending/wobble" explanation incorrect; 2) the arrows all "wobble" due to "column bending", a well-known mechanical engineering phenomenon, and the continued "wobble" is due to vibration as a result of the column bending imparted by the string during the acceleration phase of the arrow, and the resultant momentum due to the mass of the shaft; 3) if a bowman is able to see the vibration and the crossing nodes, that alone is totally amazing, but I suspect that they can't see it at all, and their brains are guessing where the head of the arrow will be at any point in its flight.

Trick shooting, like hitting an aspirin, is pretty useless for battle or hunting. Its a special skill, and its hard (don't think I'm saying anyone could do it easily, it takes practice like anything), but not useful for anything other than tricks. He doesn't draw the bow very far. The poundage on the arrow is relatively weak when he shoots something so close to him, like an aspirin from a few feet away, the arrow doesn't actually wobble nearly so much as if he shot a target 50 yards away. So, its not as tricky as it appears. He may as well be tossing the arrow at the aspirin with his hand. The serious wobble on the arrow occurs when he does a full draw and loads up the poundage. Then of course, he shoots at much larger and farther targets. And, the farther away the target the less wobble in the arrow. It eventually straightens over time/distance.  So, hitting a farther target is still pretty easy because the wobble has subsided. If that wasn't the case, archers would suck much more on average and archery would be a horrible way to hunt or kill people in battle. I would be much more impressed with hitting an aspirin from full draw with a bow that had enough power to easily kill a deer or elk.  THEN the wobble would be a serious problem and require as much sciencing as this video seems to suggest.

When I saw the title, my first thought was: "because a perfect arrow flies forever, and that's impossible..."  XD

And here I thought it was how the arrow should never arrive at the target.  I'll try and explain:  I shoot an arrow at a target 100 yards (#Y for future shorthand) away (arrow flight mechanics won;t matter for this).  Now, to reach that target, it needs to move past the half-way point right?  Let's move the arrow to 50Y, and since it hasn't hit, it needs to move past the new mid-point right?  So let's move to 75Y.  Still not there huh?  Halfway point is 12.5Y away, and needs to pass that, so skip to 87.5Y...  Notice the pattern yet?  We must always hit a halfway point, and by following this logic, the arrow should never hit as we always have a halfway point to check.  Look up the Greek philosopher Zeno and his paradoxes, in this case the fletcher's / arrow paradox for a better explanation.

Here's another point that isn't being discussed - the first node is actually extremely close to the tip of the arrow, meaning the tip doesn't deflect much at all. This is because the tip is heavier due to the arrowhead, and that increased mass moves the node further toward it. So no matter how much flailing around the rear four fifths of the arrow is doing, the tip isn't moving much at all - and it all sums up to straight flight.

There is a significant factual inaccuracy in this video. In actual practice, there is no "bow between us and the target". The archer aims using the arrow itself, as it lays on the side of the bow. While the arrow certainly bends, and the bending is important, the arrow does not actually "bend around the bow", and it does not fly to where the bow points. The arrow flies to where IT points when at full draw. That said, the video is correct that the bending prevents the arrow from flying to the left of the full draw position (the brace height direction).

If you watch other slow motion studies of arrow behavior with longbows, where they align the camera with the axis of the arrow at full draw, you can plainly see that that's what determines the left to right trajectory. The direction of the bow itself is irrelevant.

Just wanted to add a little more science to this... Part of the reason for the bend is the Law of Inertia. The arrow point has some weight to it which is usually heaviest part of the bow (per square inch). When an archer releases and arrow, the arrow point remains in place for a split second but the nock side of the arrow is moving because of the string. To conserve energy, the shaft of the arrow has to bend. Because of the elasticity of the arrow, the arrow shaft will bend one way and then bend back the other way because it wants to go back to its original straightness. As the arrow flies, the wobbling of the shaft reduces until it is straight or close to being straight. If the spine of a shaft is too weak and the arrow point is too heavy, its possible for the shaft to break. If the shaft is too stiff and the arrow point is too light, then the arrow won't bend back to its original straight shape fast enough and it will fly away in a direction that is away from the bow. There's a fine balance to find with respect to arrow point weight and shaft spine. Love this sport! :D

I have a hypothesis. I don't think it's possible that Bryon can calculate which side (positive or negative relative to the axis of the shaft nodes) the tip is vibrating on at time of impact.

He doesn't need to. Instead what happens is the frequency of vibration is so quick that if you drop anything from around human height, the maximum speed it can attain during its fall is low compared to the speed of the arrow tip during most of it's vibration.

So all that needs to be calculated in Bryon's head is the line trajectory. If he gets the shaft axis of the arrow to point within a few degrees of the target during impact, the quickness of the vibrations will sweep and hit everything in an arc in front.

I could be wrong, but this is a much more reasonable explanation than Bryon factoring in air drag of arrow, aspirin, timing the release so precisely it eliminates the possibility of one half cycle of vibration offset and doing it all in the span of a second. I know humans after practicing for decades get crazy good/amazing at what they do, but this is, in my understanding, outside human capability. I'll believe it if you can show me a video of Bryon holding his hand steady from any sort of twitching.

Paradoxes aren't just two things that contradict eachother, paradox specifically references impossible situations where there is a loop of contradiction, where one thing must lead to the other, but that 'other' contradicts the 'one thing' at the start. In other words it's an impossible situation that makes you think "the first thing makes this second thing happen, but that second thing means the first thing can't have happened, but the second thing wasn't there to stop the first thing when it happened" etc.

If the arrows spline is to stiff or soft then the arrow will miss the intended target center to either side.  if the correct splined arrow is used then the arrow will hit the center of the intended target center. The main idea is the proper splined arrow for a particular setup. However, there's no magic here. He chooses arrows with a spine that will straighten the arrow at whatever distance he's shooting. All of the exhibition shooting I've seen him do are at about 10 yards or less. So he chooses an arrow spine that will stop flexing before it hits whatever he's aiming at. Then it's just a matter of having perfect form, incredible concentration, inhuman consistency, and decades of practice. Piece of cake, right?.

i know i'm about to blabber a lot about bows and this video is great but i got a little niggle with some things

i don't know what bow they keep calling the long bow but i know what a longbow is
 and its not that a longbow is about as big or bigger than a man and takes a great amount of strength to string.

in medieval england they had boys practice using the bow from the age of 8  every day of the year they had almost deformed arms from how strong their pulling arm was from years of practice and could string a longbow without effort and the arrows they shot could pierce any armour and knock a man off his feet.

i shot one once and its really difficult i managed to pull it back using a method of posture the teach you at the archers club to use your back muscles when pulling instead of straining on your neck if you position your arm to push against your body
however having little practice with such a powerful bow hitting the target even when really close was extremely difficult. 

however i'd like to point out I've only really started out doing archery so i'm no expert but a grandmaster archer told me and showed me some longbows and i saw they have a different shape they don't have a flat face they're smooth all around and made of two bits of wood i can't remember what the guy said the technique was for welding these two different parts toghether but  its not simple and it takes a craftsman of great skill to produce one

in fact speaking of shape i think the bow they keep referring to as the longbow is actually a flatbow

also not just compound bows shoot down the middle most recurve bows do by making a special cut into the wood and having a rest however its a little less sophisticated than a compound bow and takes a bit more effort to use so you need to shoot into the bow as they say which is a lot of different little details about how you stand how your hand rests against the bow as you pull it if your arm is outstretched and locked then you need to bring it back so you arm acts more like a spring for example if you tried to carry a heavy weight with a completely straight back your liable to have it snap because all the energy is focused in a straight line whereas with a bend it has a bit of give and acts more like a spring then all you need to do it control where the energy from that spring in your arm goes so its up against your side of your body using your back muscles instead of pushing you arm off and behind your body putting strain on the neck muscles.

anyway thats just me geeking out about some things i learnt about bows if you know more than me i welcome the notion of being enlightened for i am a nooby

its not archers paradox...its about time in physics

ah I always thought the archers paradox was one of Zeno's puzzles... but apparently that is called the arrow paradox.

If everything when it occupies an equal space is at rest, and if that which is in locomotion is always occupying such a space at any moment, the flying arrow is therefore motionless.
– as recounted by Aristotle, Physics VI:9, 239b5

In the arrow paradox (also known as the fletcher's paradox), Zeno states that for motion to occur, an object must change the position which it occupies. He gives an example of an arrow in flight. He states that in any one (durationless) instant of time, the arrow is neither moving to where it is, nor to where it is not. It cannot move to where it is not, because no time elapses for it to move there; it cannot move to where it is, because it is already there. In other words, at every instant of time there is no motion occurring. If everything is motionless at every instant, and time is entirely composed of instants, then motion is impossible.

I've been an archer for 56 of my 60 years, and until about two years ago, I didn't even know that ALL arrows flex like they do. I'd never seen a slow motion film until Mythbusters did an episode on archery. And I never knew about the 'Paradox'... I just shot, I didn't really aim. I just pulled and shot all in one smooth motion, (I never owned a compound bow, and only shot one once. Didn't care for it. Lazy man's tool) I draw and release all in one motion, and I generally hit what I'm shooting at. I did notice that distance made a difference, and as little as a foot or so could affect my shots. This was easy to correct for...  I never hunted anything but rabbits and birds. (Birds are harder to hit, but not by as much as you might think. That was as a kid. I quit all hunting in '86) I made my first bows (And arrows) out of my kite sticks, kite string that I'd braid, and real feathers. All this was back in the '50's,'till my dad bought me a real bow at age 5. I still have the 25lb fiberglass bow I got for my 11th birthday. I still shoot it once in a while... 5 decades after I got it. I wonder if any of that had anything to do with me being made a small arms instructor during the Vietnam war? I could shoot anything, and I've noticed, if you can shoot a bow, you can shoot a slingshot and vice-verse.

The real reason why he can hit the aspirin is his cerebellum - the part of the brain responsible for the co-ordination of movement which combines sensory input such as proprioception and visuo-spacial processing with motor output.  The cerebellum is very poorly understood in terms of how it achieves what it does.  Even if you consider catching a ball as it moves through the air this is not a straightforward task.  It requires a prediction of where that ball is going to be as well as the correctly co-ordinated sequence of muscle contractions which will enable the hand to be in the correct place to catch the ball.

The nervous signals sent to achieve this also take a certain amount of time to reach the muscles meaning that the signals must be sent in advance.  It is essentially relying heavily on an accurate model of where the ball is and where it will be in relation to where you are.  You are not fully conscious of all of this processing and if you try to take over the function of the cerebellum with conscious thought you will usually perform far worse.  It is a form of reasoning which does not translate well into conscious thought and language.  

Catching a ball may seem simple as it is not difficult.  However, once you have a system like a cerebellum capable of making accurate enough sense of the world to reliably catch a ball then you have something which is capable of far more.

That was interessting to see. I practice Kyudo, japanese archery, and we have an different approche to deal with the archers paradox. First our arrow is resting on the right side of the bow and not the left side but the arrow would still be deflected away from the target, yust to the other direction. So we turn the bow to the left at the moment of the release (to be precise, the force produced by turning the bow is the reson for the release). So we turn the bow out of the way of the arrow. If done correctly this does not only ensure that the arrow is flying straight to the target but also gives the arrow a little bit more energy.

There's a little more magic to this. The paradox I was taught is the redistribution of stored energy. The arrow actually stores energy gained on release and it cannot disperse it so it flexes. The arrow is gaining speed, or at least slowing its natural decrease, due to it straightening and that energy actually provides forward inertia. The flex amount decreases as energy is used. How an arrow stores, redistributes energy  and slows the natural decrease of an object in flight is truly interesting and the paradox I had confused the scholastic definition with.

I've seen bows that use magnets so that the arrow can be pointed at the target without the bow interfering.  Basically, where the point where the bow would block the line of sight to the target has a gap and magnets are used to balance the front of the arrow between the two points, meaning you have to have at least a little bit of metal in the front of the arrow.

No idea if the bow made it past the prototype stage, but this was a long time ago.  I'm personally wondering if people even care about the notion of bows that don't block line of sight, maybe the blocking action is considered part of the challenge of the sport.

AH, so the mirror shot taught us something about the wobbling of the arrow. Since the wobbling nodes (where there is no wobbling) is so close to the tip and nock of every arrow, in reality, our archer does not need to worry about trying to time the wobble of his arrow with the distance and power of the shot. Looking at that high speed, it looks like the tip only wobbles about one centimeter up or down, and since he does not need to hit the aspirin exactly on the middle of the tip of the arrow, the wobble uncertainty is small enough that some part of the tip will always hit a target directly in line with the arrow no matter at what stage of the wobble the arrow is in. Notice that his aspirin shot was done with a flat arrow tip, so that even of the edge of the arrow hit the aspirin, it would still break it. I would say that he specifically designed or at least chose that tip to be as flat as it is so that he can do this. As long as the archer can counteract the archer's paradox and shoot the arrow directly at the target, he will hit the aspirin.

Here's an additional tidbit: The the traditional japanese asymmetrical bow, the Yumi (which comes in the smaller Hankyu and larger Daikyu varieties) solves the archer's paradox by utilizing a precise and difficult technique known as Kyudo, in which the bow is twisted to the side as it's fired. This not only adds pressure to the string and therefore power to the shot, but also moves the upper limb where the arrow is nocked out to the side, leaving the arrow free to fire in a straight(ish) line

In (spin) knife-throwing, it's simple enough to get the knife to stick straight in despite the fact that the knife is spinning because we can relate the rotation of the knife as it hits the target with our distance from the target and adjust our distance accordingly.

I'd imagine a similar method is used in adjusting for the archer's paradox - The arrow seems to bend in a somewhat harmonic oscillatory way, as long as have an idea of the oscillation frequency and also the distance covered by the arrow, you'll know the orientation of the arrow when it hits.

He can get the touch and hit more than the average, but he cannot predict the wobbling of the arrow (it's a complex system even for a computer with all the initial conditions).
